title: Southwest Airlines pilot plays Top Gun song on take-off
text:
9 shares 3
View
comments
This Southwest Airlines crew scored points with passengers – and maybe even startled a few – with its choice of song during take-off on a recent flight.
Footage captured by a passenger reveals the moment the Kenny Loggins song ‘Danger Zone’, from the 1986 film Top Gun, blared through the cabin as the plane barrelled down the runway.
A male flight attendant seated just outside the cockpit door played the role of Goose as he recreated scenes and shouted ‘commands’ to the pilots over the tannoy.
Maverick! Southwest Airline attendant plays Top Gun on take-off The flight attendant (left) recreated scenes as the Southwest Airlines plane took off
In the 30-second clip, the song is heard over the rumble of the engines as the flight attendant twice takes to the tannoy to recreate scenes from the cult hit starring Tom Cruise, who portrayed a young naval pilot nicknamed Maverick.
At one point, the flight attendant, who is clearly enjoying the moment, says: ‘You gotta get up there, Mav. They’re moving in for a shot.’
 Holidaymaker's fury after currency exchange shop gave her... The seals outnumber the guests! Scottish holiday island with... Hotels in Spanish holiday hotspot of Lloret de Mar given... He ran out of countries! Meet the youngest person to visit... Moments later, he shouts: ‘OK. Ready, Maverick? Do a barrel roll. No, I’m just kidding we’re not going to do that.’
The clip was recorded by a passenger who was seated in an aisle near the front of the plane.
MailOnline Travel has contacted Southwest Airlines for comment.
The 1986 film Top Gun starred Tom Cruise as Maverick, a young naval pilot
The video has more than 150,000 views on YouTube, where a number of viewers appreciated the crew’s attempt at creating a light-hearted moment.
One Quote: : ‘Why doesn’t this ever happen when I fly? I hate flying and need some humour to lighten things up.’
But some weren’t impressed and questioned whether rules were broken.
One Quote: : ‘Playing music over the PA during one of the most critical phases of flight. Yeah, hilarious.’
Another said: ‘Entertaining, but not the best decision a critical phase of flight.’
